meta.title: The Dictatorship of Woke Capital: How Political Correctness Captured Big Business
meta.author: Stephen R. Soukup

parts.title: Woke Capital: Redefining Modern Finance
parts.body: Woke Capital is a term becoming central in modern finance, led by BlackRock's CEO, Larry Fink. In early 2020, amid the pandemic, the U.S. government partnered with them for economic recovery. Fink stresses sustainability as a new investment standard, aligning with global financial leaders. The push for ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) policies in business reflects a shift in evaluating companies not just by profit, but by social responsibility. However, many see this as bypassing democratic processes, sparking debates on the power dynamics in capitalism.

parts.title: The Shifts in Political and Wall Street Alliances
parts.body: In the transition from Republican to Democratic power in the 1930s, Roosevelt connected with the people on a populist level, promising to save them from the Depression. Despite being a patrician, Roosevelt focused on restoring the credibility of the Democratic Party by shifting the focus from Wall Street "fat cats" to the needs of everyday Americans. This populist image of the Democrats became deeply ingrained, seen in cultural depictions of Republicans as out of touch. Over time, this rhetoric evolved, particularly highlighted during the 1992 election, identifying George H.W. Bush with the decade of greed, contrasting with Bill Clinton, who portrayed himself as a champion for the middle class. The irony was that despite Clinton’s anti-Wall Street campaign messaging, he leaned heavily on Wall Street insiders like Robert Rubin for policy formulation, including the Glass-Steagall repeal. This shift highlights a blurred connection between Democrats and American finance, undermining the stereotype that Republicans were solely allied with Wall Street. The details show the shifting alliances in NY politics where Democrats like Clinton benefited from Wall Street connections, signaling a democratic hold over what was traditionally Republican—a pivotal transformation in American political narratives.

parts.title: Cultural Marxism and its Development
parts.body: Antonio Gramsci, an Italian Marxist, was imprisoned by Mussolini aiming to stop his influential thoughts. Gramsci examined why revolutions were backward from Marx's expectations, pondering why nationalism turned socialists into fascists. Gramsci concluded that cultural conflict was central, arguing a cultural revolution must precede an economic one, destroying the old culture to build a new one. Christianity was seen as a dominant cultural force that needed dismantling to liberate workers from bourgeois culture. Sinópolis Relevance: In Hungary, György Lukács, a Marxist intellectual, also examined cultural influence during Communist efforts to reshape society through education. His work in cultural Marxism influenced the Frankfurt School, a think tank where important Marxist ideas were developed further. Under Max Horkheimer, critical theory emerged, aiming to not just understand society but critique and change it. By challenging positivism, they highlighted society as a restraining construct. When Horkheimer moved the institute to the U.S., merging Freudian psychoanalysis with Marxism, it led to a substantial shift in American academia.

parts.title: Misuse of Stakeholder Analysis
parts.body: ## Misuse of Stakeholder Analysis The normative model created in stakeholder analysis led to misleading interpretations as it failed to clarify differences from other models. This resulted in poor analysis in both academic and business spheres, complicating the core stakeholder analysis concept. The model encouraged “value-directed” questions, leading to confusion over which values best serve the analysis. Critics also identified a lack of transparency regarding differences between normative principles and practical objectives, causing more complications in managing businesses effectively and ethically.

parts.title: Socially Responsible Investing & Shareholder Dynamics
parts.body: Chapter 6 discusses socially responsible investing (SRI), tracing it back to John Wesley and his ethical guidelines, and highlighting its evolution through key events and figures. Wesley advocated for ethical earning, saving, and giving, emphasizing that money should not harm life or health. The modern SRI movement notably began with Phillip Carret's exclusion of alcohol and tobacco investments in the 1928 Pioneer Fund. The 1971 Pax World Balanced Fund launch, driven by two United Methodist ministers, marked significant progress, aiming to avoid war profits during Vietnam. Section one of Chapter 8 introduces the battleground of public companies, elucidating the dynamics of private versus public ownership. Public companies allow anyone to purchase shares openly, while private entities are more selective. A pivotal example is Chick-fil-A, which, thanks to its private status, withstands social activist pressures unlike a public counterpart that might easily succumb. The role of shareholders, their rights, and how they interact with board-directed companies are covered, illustrating how activist shareholders can exert influence by proposing changes directly or through proxy services, like Institutional Shareholder Service (ISS) and Glass-Lewis.

parts.title: Public Pension Activism
parts.body: CalPERS, a large public pension fund, has been criticized for making investment decisions based on political, social, and environmental causes instead of focusing on maximizing returns. This has led to poor performance, particularly in ESG-focused funds. Surprisingly, despite previous public stances against investing, CalPERS now holds significant investments in China, stirring national security concerns. NYCERS, another public pension plan invested heavily in ESG, also faces subpar returns, with a large amount in unfunded liabilities. The section discusses how these funds prioritize activism over financial performance, affecting their stability.

parts.title: Tim Cook & Apple's ESG and Activism
parts.body: Tim Cook, CEO of Apple, sent a memo addressing racism in the US after George Floyd's death. Cook highlighted that Apple's mission is to empower and include everyone. Cook's stance differs from founder Steve Jobs as Cook is known to be a CEO activist. Apple is seen as a leader in ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance). They've pledged to be carbon-neutral since the early 2010s and have taken bold actions to support social justice, including $100 million for racial equity and strong stances on renewable energy. However, there’s controversy as Apple's contractors might not fully use renewables, suggesting greenwashing.

parts.title: Amazon’s SPLC Controversy and Charitable Issues
parts.body: This section explores the controversial influence of the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) on Amazon's charitable program, AmazonSmile. Amazon uses the SPLC's list to decide which charities can receive funding, but SPLC has been criticized for misusing funds and unfairly labeling certain conservative and religious groups as "hate groups". One significant victim was the Family Research Council, which faced violence due to such labeling by SPLC. SPLC, despite its controversial practices, ranks among the top beneficiaries of AmazonSmile. Critics argue that partnering with SPLC poses a reputational risk to Amazon since they are seen to support an organization that unjustly defames others and has questionable operations. Additionally, Jeff Bezos, Amazon's CEO, has faced backlash due to connections with the Washington Post, which sometimes aligns with SPLC's critical stance on certain groups. Bezos, while personally not directly involved, has indirectly supported SPLC through company policies, raising ethical concerns and highlighting the political dimension influencing business decisions.

parts.title: Corporations Under Scrutiny for Ethics and Practices
parts.body: Some corporations have come under scrutiny for their environmental and labor practices. For instance, Apple has been criticized for its dependence on China, particularly through its association with Foxconn—a company known for rigorous working conditions. Apple has made strides toward a "carbon-free" future and joined ESG movements, naming philanthropic efforts like donations to the Equal Justice Initiative. Despite these efforts, accusations of hypocrisy persist, citing their tax practices and lawsuits related to labor conditions. Apple's dependency further ties them to larger geopolitical conversations and adds layers to their public image issues. Criticism also encompasses Amazon, particularly for its working conditions and affiliations. The company experienced pushback regarding its relationship with the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), which is critiqued for political bias and hate group labeling. Amazon attempted to align itself with social justice movements, contributing substantial donations to "social justice organizations". However, internal issues, including employee unrest during the coronavirus pandemic, highlight criticisms from within about ethical missteps and corporate responsibility. Both Apple and Amazon exemplify the tensions multinationals face in ethical operations while balancing shareholder expectations.
